body_content.explanation: to fail to do or experience something, often something planned or expected, or to avoid doing or experiencing something:
examples: I missed the start of the class because my bus was late.
Often I miss (= do not eat) breakfast and have an early lunch instead.
You should leave early if you want to miss the rush hour.
I only just missed being run over by a bus this morning.

body_content.explanation: to arrive too late to get on a bus, train, or aircraft:
examples: You'll miss your flight if you don't hurry up.
Students who miss a lot of school can find it hard to catch up.
I'm trying to find an excuse for missing the office party.

body_content.explanation: to not see or hear something or someone:
examples: I missed the beginning of the show.
Her latest movie is too good to miss (= it certainly should be seen).
I was sorry I missed you at Pat's party - I must have arrived after you left.

body_content.explanation: to not notice someone or something:
examples: You don't miss much, do you? Nobody else noticed that mistake.
My office is first on the right with a bright red door. You can't miss it (= it is very easy to find).
A big neon sign has been put up where nobody can miss it.
A golden eagle is so large and distinctive that no birdwatcher, however inexperienced, could possibly miss it.

body_content.explanation: to feel sad that a person or thing is not present:
examples: I really missed her when she went away.
She will be sadly missed by all who knew her.
I still miss my old car.
What did you miss most about home when you were living in France?
I haven't missed smoking like I expected to.

body_content.explanation: to fail to hit something, or to avoid hitting something:
examples: The bullet missed his heart by a couple of centimetres.
I swerved to avoid the other car and only just missed a tree.
He threw a book at me, but he/it missed.

body_content.explanation: to notice that something is lost or absent:
examples: He didn't miss his wallet until the waiter brought the bill.

body_content.explanation: an occasion when something or someone fails to hit something or avoids hitting something:
examples: Well done! You scored eight hits and only two misses.

body_content.explanation: to avoid or not do something:
examples: We usually go to France in the summer, but we've decided to give it a miss this year.

body_content.explanation: a girl or young woman, especially one who behaves rudely or shows no respect:
examples: You're a cheeky little miss! Apologize at once.

body_content.explanation: a title used before the family name or full name of a single woman who has no other title:
examples: Dr White will see you now, Miss Carter.
Miss Helena Lewis

body_content.explanation: used as a form of address for a girl or young woman:
examples: Excuse me, Miss, you dropped this.

body_content.explanation: sometimes used by children to address or refer to teachers who are women:
examples: Can I go to the toilet, Miss?

body_content.explanation: a title given to a woman who wins a beauty contest, combined with the name of the place that she represents:
examples: Miss India/UK
the Miss World contest
